reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s treatment of space/resource governance, alleging an implicit “unified agent” assumption and claiming that defection/first-mover incentives dominate, so moral-view convergence is irrelevant. This is only moderately central: (i) the essay’s main thesis is that near-best futures are a narrow target because value is fragile across many moral dimensions and many plausible value functions are fussy; (ii) space resource allocation is just one illustrative dimension among many. Even if the critique landed, it would mostly add another way futures go wrong rather than overturn “no easy eutopia.” Strength is low because the critique doesn’t actually refute the core argument and, if anything, supports the conclusion that good futures are hard (it introduces an additional coordination failure mode). It also overclaims that the authors “ignore” defection/first-mover issues; the essay explicitly discusses first-come claims and resulting concentration/lock-in as a moral-catastrophe route. Correctness is mixed: it’s broadly right that strategic incentives and race dynamics could matter a lot and could block ideal allocation even with shared ideals, but it’s too strong to say the game-theoretic structure “ensures” defection or makes the whole framework “decision-theoretically naive,” especially given the essay’s scope (this installment focuses on target size, not navigation/coordination). The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Game-theoretic defection incentives undermine the paper's unified agent assumption
